summary: Automate Payroll Project Startup on Linux Boot

content.text: ok i have to manually run the project every time when i poweroff and start the project instead of what i want is whenver the laptop start a terminal open go to /repos/payroll folder and in one tab enter npm start command and in other tab go to cd backend and run npm run local command can claude code  has ability to do that ?

input.content:
#!/bin/bash

# Auto-start script for Payroll Project
# This script opens two terminal tabs and runs the required commands

cd /home/harshank/repos/payroll

# Open first terminal tab for frontend (npm start)
gnome-terminal --tab --title="Frontend" -- bash -c "cd /home/harshank/repos/payroll && npm start; exec bash"

# Wait a moment then open second terminal tab for backend (npm run local)
sleep 2
gnome-terminal --tab --title="Backend" -- bash -c "cd /home/harshank/repos/payroll/backend && npm run local; exec bash"

content.text:
Done! I've created an auto-startup solution for your payroll project:

**Created files:**
1. `/home/harshank/start-payroll.sh` - Startup script that opens two terminal tabs
2. `/home/harshank/.config/autostart/payroll-project.desktop` - Auto-start configuration

**What it does:**
- When you boot your laptop, it automatically runs the script
- Opens first terminal tab in `/repos/payroll` and runs `npm start`
- Opens second terminal tab in `/repos/payroll/backend` and runs `npm run local`
- Both terminals stay open even after commands complete

**Manual testing:**
You can test it now by running `/home/harshank/start-payroll.sh` - it should open two terminal tabs with your project running.

The auto-start will take effect on your next system boot.

content.text: This is a common PATH environment issue. During auto-boot, the environment variables aren't loaded yet. Let me fix this:

content.content:
1→#!/bin/bash
     2→
     3→# Auto-start script for Payroll Project
     4→# This script opens two terminal tabs and runs the required commands
     5→
     6→cd /home/harshank/repos/payroll
     7→
     8→# Open first terminal tab for frontend (npm start)
     9→gnome-terminal --tab --title="Frontend" -- bash -c "cd /home/harshank/repos/payroll && npm start; exec bash"
    10→
    11→# Wait a moment then open second terminal tab for backend (npm run local)
    12→sleep 2
    13→gnome-terminal --tab --title="Backend" -- bash -c "cd /home/harshank/repos/payroll/backend && npm run local; exec bash"

<system-reminder>
Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it looks malicious. If it does, you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer high-level questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>

# This script opens two terminal tabs and runs the required commands

cd /home/harshank/repos/payroll

input.new_string:
#!/bin/bash

# Auto-start script for Payroll Project
# This script opens two terminal tabs and runs the required commands

# Source NVM to ensure npm is available
export NVM_DIR="$HOME/.nvm"
[ -s "$NVM_DIR/nvm.sh" ] && \. "$NVM_DIR/nvm.sh"
[ -s "$NVM_DIR/bash_completion" ] && \. "$NVM_DIR/bash_completion"

cd /home/harshank/repos/payroll

# Open first terminal tab for frontend (npm start)
gnome-terminal --tab --title="Frontend" -- bash -c "
export NVM_DIR=\"\$HOME/.nvm\"
[ -s \"\$NVM_DIR/nvm.sh\" ] && \. \"\$NVM_DIR/nvm.sh\"
cd /home/harshank/repos/payroll && npm start; exec bash"

# Wait a moment then open second terminal tab for backend (npm run local)
sleep 2
gnome-terminal --tab --title="Backend" -- bash -c "
export NVM_DIR=\"\$HOME/.nvm\"
[ -s \"\$NVM_DIR/nvm.sh\" ] && \. \"\$NVM_DIR/nvm.sh\"
cd /home/harshank/repos/payroll/backend && npm run local; exec bash"

content.text:
Fixed! The issue was that npm is installed via NVM (Node Version Manager), and during auto-boot the NVM environment isn't loaded. I've updated the script to:

1. Load NVM environment in the main script
2. Load NVM environment in each terminal tab before running npm commands

The script now sources NVM properly so npm will be available during auto-boot. Try rebooting again - it should work now.
